intro: Corydalis idahoensis, commonly known as Idaho poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its delicate, papery petals and bright yellow-orange flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in forested areas or along streambanks. It has slender, branched stems and trifoliate leaves, which are divided into three leaflets. Corydalis idahoensis is a member of the Papaveraceae family and is known for its ornamental value and ecological importance in its native habitat.
